nodes.text: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) based eigenface method can provide a practical, efficient face recognition system suitable for constrained environments
Face images are represented as vectors and a training set of centered, same-size face images defines a high dimensional space for PCA

Eigenfaces are computed by subtracting the mean face, forming the covariance structure, and obtaining the principal eigenvectors; computational efficiency is improved by computing eigenvectors of the M x M matrix L rather than the full covariance matrix
Recognition is performed by projecting images onto the K-dimensional eigenface subspace, computing weight vectors, and classifying by minimum Euclidean distance between feature weight vectors
The implementation was developed in MATLAB and tested on an image database (ETE-07 series, RUET) composed of student face images of size 200 x 149 pixels
Each training face image is converted to an MN by 1 vector; the mean face vector is computed and subtracted from each image to produce centered difference vectors
The M eigenvectors of the small matrix L correspond to the largest eigenvectors of the full covariance matrix and are used to form the eigenface basis; low-eigenvalue eigenfaces can be omitted
A test face is projected into eigenface space to compute its weight vector and classified by finding the training weight vector with minimum Euclidean distance; this distance measures similarity
Experimental setup used 36 face images of 18 persons from ETE-07 series, RUET for initial testing
The implementation processed Bitmap, PNG, and JPEG images and was designed for centered frontal face images
Experimental results show successful recognition when test and database images have the same pose (high accuracy in same-pose tests)
Experimental results show the method yields good classification with some robustness to pose variation but has limitations with variations in image size
The eigenface PCA approach is fast, relatively simple, and provides a practical solution for face recognition in constrained environments
Limitation: the method performs less well with variations in image size and is best suited to constrained, frontal or near-frontal face images
Future work proposed: extend system to real-time video, enlarge database beyond 36 images, handle varying image sizes, and compare PCA performance with other recognition methods
